comments.body: The question is why add danger to danger if they want the place to be more liveable
These ideas are all great and mix well with the warped forest ideas that make the nether more lively and interesting
Maybe springs could sometimes spawn in basalt deltas. Also the Netheresian shouldn't be able to turn lava into obsidian for balancing.
Interesting. Do not know how it would be done, but I like it, this terraforming idea.

Wow, I'm surprised this post has so few upvotes, because it would actually open so many more possibilities !
This is becoming even more needed with the introduction of vibrant visuals, with biome tinted sky color, where if you wanted to make a very big desert it would look very weird because the sky wouldn't be the right color at some places, and with the pale garden biome, where if you were building a base on a mountain side there would be a constant fog at a specific location.
ok boomer

I very much agree and it is the main reason I don't like building in Savannahs and Deserts. I remember in one world building a bridge over a river between two Savannah biomes. During rainy weather, only the river and bridge had rain - it looked very odd. 

Perhaps Mojang could set a variable that no rain appears in rivers located next to 'hot biomes' OR remove rivers as biomes, setting them more like spawn-able structures. Either way, this is something I really want to be implemented.

Absolutely agreed. Badlands are my favorite biome, at least to look at, but the fact that it rains in rivers cutting through arid areas is such a huge turnoff for me, because it's not realistic. I also enjoy Minecraft rain a great deal, so I'm looking into mods that will make it rain in those biomes, instead.
Great Idea! There could also be ruins around the lake bed, like old, ruined mudhouses or something and dried trees.

Yesü•π
Good idea! Just what I was thinking!
Would be especially cool if they generated at really high y-levels, on the sides of enormous mountains, like real cloud forests. I'm not sure if graveyards fit the cloud forest's aesthetic though.

In Minecraft Live 2020 we saw a screenshot of the new mountain generation, in this screenshot the clouds are very low and this leads me to believe that the generation will start featuring much higher features. I think it would spawn on top of high rocky plateaus and there would jungle trees on top of them. If this biome where in the game I think it could have a special weather event: fog, fog would be a weather event that makes it very hard to see, it would be white and misty and you would only see the outlines of objects through the fog. I also have an idea for a yeti mob that would be very scary and be about as large and strong as the warden mob from the cave update, although it wouldn't be blind making it very dangerous. Another mob that could be implemented would be the roc, the roc is a large bird of prey in middle eastern mythology that I think would be perfect for this biome. It would be a boss mob that would have a nest high up in the mountains and it would swoop down and pick up the player dropping them from a high height dealing fall damage. Beating the roc would reward the player with a rocs feather which is an item from MC Dungeons, holding it and right clicking would send the player high into the air which would be very useful for elytra flight. This is an edited version of the suggestion I wrote out and then realized that it was already a suggestion, anyways I hope this added to your idea as this would be a very cool biome to have in the game!

Swamps and marsh are completely different. Swamps are have trees and are relatively humid. Marshes are more welcoming and are flat. there's a lot of mud and are great for bird watching. You'll see very different animals between the two.

Mine too

Especially with the bioluminescence of skulk, an Abyss could definitely be incredible! This is the best iteration of an "Abyss" biome I have seen yet! Others are too far fetched but this would fit well with other Minecraft concepts and biomes. I feel like this concept fits the "Minecraft Game Design" (2019) by by Jens Bergensten in several ways. Firstly, it expands "The Mysteries" (Bergensten, 35). Though partially subjective, I feel that this additionally feels very "Vanilla" (Bergensten, 65). I believe that because a trench can be seen even from elytra height that this biome would fit well with the rule "Finding things is fun. Searching for them is not" (Bergensten, 53). Finally, I feel that Minecraft has been excellent at being silly however, I think that the Warden has been a step in the right direction. This biome would be a great way to expand on the rule "Minecraft is scary" (Bergensten, 25). Many mods try to add a scary monster but some of the most memorable scary elements of Minecraft are environmental, such as cave sounds. A trench or Abyss is perfect for Minecraft's type of scary. After all, the ocean is one of the scariest places in real life! I would love to see Minecraft's take on the scariness of the depths! Lastly, an Abyss adds to "Exploration" and "Adventure" (Bergensten, 7, 8)!

In the Minecraft Live they showed those Azealia "bushes" or whatever those were, I thought looked so cute like little bonsai versions of the full tree. I hope they add more stuff like that because it adds a foliage-size in between tiny flowers on the ground and full-sized giant trees. There's not much foliage like that so rounds out a niche.

I would image this as a variant of the birch forest that forms at higher elevations. I would love for the Aspen leaves to be a bright yellowish orange with a whiteish gray wood color.
My family has a tradition to go hiking up a trail called Kenosha pass which was filled with beautiful aspen forest, so adding aspens has always been. An important goal for me
